<a href="https://www.fool.com/the-ascent/credit-cards/landing/chase-freedom-flex-credit-card/?utm_site=theascent&utm_campaign=ta-cc-co-mb-chafreeflx-02132021-5-na-na&utm_medium=cpc&utm_source=mb" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="The Ascent" style="width:100%;max-width: 165px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="165" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby8yOC8xNTk3ODU4MTU0LVRoZUFzY2VudC1Mb2dvX18xXy5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJjb21ldC1tb3JuaW5nYnJldyIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19"></a>

<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning and Happy Galentine’s Day.</strong> For those of you who think we just made a typo, Galentine’s Day is a holiday celebrating female friendship, and was invented by Leslie Knope in Season 2 of <em>Parks and Recreation</em>. Waffles are typically involved.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As Knope explains: “Every February 13, my lady friends and I leave our husbands and our boyfriends at home and we just come and kick it, breakfast-style.” If you celebrate, we'd love to hear your unique traditions.</p>
</td>
</tr>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/02/12/sponsors-struggle-navigate-complicated-olympic-landscape?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brands Confront Olympic-Sized Controversy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Two people standing behind human sized Olympic rings" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MDUyL29seW1waWNfcmluZ3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Carl Court/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You might think that running 100 meters in under 10 seconds or landing a Double McTwist 1260 would be the hardest things to do at the Olympics. But corporate sponsors are navigating an even bigger challenge: the delicate geopolitical and social issues surrounding the next two Olympics, in Tokyo and Beijing. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>More than 180 rights groups have </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/2022-beijing-winter-olympics-boycott-china-759c66df-df19-4f1b-92a1-744b98276dc9.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called for a boycott</a></span><span> of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, citing the Chinese government’s many reported human rights violations. </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>And yesterday, the president of the Tokyo Olympic organizing committee, Yoshiro Mori, </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/11/world/asia/yoshiro-mori-tokyo-olympics-resigns.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">resigned</a></span><span> after facing major blowback over his suggestion that women talk too much in meetings. Part of that blowback: Corporate sponsors started to rethink their involvement with the Games, according to Japanese media. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It’s left brands between a scandal and a hard place</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When China’s economy bounced back from the pandemic more quickly than Western countries, businesses became <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/olympic-sponsors-face-a-balancing-act-at-the-2022-beijing-games-11613145588?mod=hp_lead_pos11&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">even more reliant</a> on Chinese consumers. Nike, for instance, grew revenue 24% in China last quarter, compared to just 1% growth in North America.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">What happens when you </strong></span><span><strong style="color:#000"><em>do</em></strong></span><span><strong style="color:#000"> speak out against China? </strong></span><span>Look at the NBA. It just returned to air in China nearly a year after former Houston Rockets GM Daryl Morey threw the league’s business relationship with Beijing into chaos after tweeting support for Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, many advertisers are desperate for the eyeballs and brand association that come from having their logo next to a hand-springing Simone Biles. Live TV viewership was way down during Covid, and the Olympics were supposed to be a bounce-back moment for television advertising. But now the picture is murkier...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>...especially because the pandemic isn’t over. Japan won’t start vaccinating citizens until the </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/03/sports/olympics/tokyo-olympics-playbook.html?action=click&module=RelatedLinks&pgtype=Article&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">end of February</a></span><span>, and the Olympics are scheduled to start in July. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>For Beijing 2022, brands might get cover from the US government. The Biden administration has signaled that it <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2022-beijing-usa/u-s-signals-no-plans-to-boycott-2022-beijing-winter-olympics-after-genocide-designation-idUSKBN2A332Z?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">doesn't support a boycott</a> of the Games.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/02/12/uk-suffers-biggest-economic-drop-300-years?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Britain’s Economy Is Worse Than Its Weather
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="LONDON, ENGLAND - DECEMBER 28: Fog over the Houses of Parliament on Dece..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MDUzL2Zlc3RpdmVfc2Vhc29uX2xlc3NfZmVzdGkuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Hollie Adams/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The UK economy just posted its <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/12/uk-economy-shrank-by-9point9percent-in-2020-its-largest-contraction-on-record.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">largest annual drop</a> since Sir Isaac Newton was figuring out why things drop. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">According to the Bank of England, 2020’s 9.9% contraction was the biggest blow to output since 1709, when the economy tanked 13% due to the “Great Frost”—the coldest European winter in the last 500+ years.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The 9.9% decline is more than double the GDP shrinkage that occured in 2009 following the financial crisis.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>It’s also a </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-britain-economy/uk-economy-slumps-by-record-10-in-2020-after-covid-hit-idUSKBN2AC0LA?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">steeper drop</a></span><span> than most other wealthy countries, including the US—whose economy fell 3.5% in 2020. Analysts say that could be because Britain’s economy relies more on face-to-face contact and recreation.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And despite tight restrictions on movement and business, the UK’s population still suffered greatly from the coronavirus, recording the highest death toll in Europe. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the UK could see a Ted Lasso-style turnaround in 2021. It’s outraced its peers in approving and distributing vaccines, and consumers appear ready to open their wallets once the pandemic dies down (hopefully) by the summer.</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COSMETICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/02/12/loral-strong-q4-says-2021-looks-promising?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
L’Oréal Is Getting Gatsby Vibes
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Gatsby raising a wine glass" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=281 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/sp685iuIEGuys/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Gatsby raising a wine glass" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/sp685iuIEGuys/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">L’Oréal must have been sticking to a consistent skincare routine, because the French cosmetics giant is positively glowing after reporting <a href="https://www.barrons.com/articles/strong-earnings-lifted-loreal-stock-analysts-think-theres-more-to-come-51613137437?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">better than expected</a> Q4 earnings yesterday. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Sales in the last three months of the year grew 4.8% on a like-for-like basis, despite the broader luxury goods market taking a pandemic nosedive.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The two main drivers of higher sales? E-commerce and China. Well, actually, more like e-commerce <em>in</em> China. Chinese online sales gained 56% (and total China revenue grew 27% in 2020).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But like the Bucs when they signed Tom Brady, L’Oréal thinks the best is yet to come. The next years will “be like the Roaring 20s, there will be a fiesta in makeup and in fragrances,” L’Oréal CEO and Chairman Jean-Paul Agon <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-l-oreal-results/loreal-sees-post-pandemic-roaring-20s-driving-cosmetics-rebound-idUSKBN2AB26T?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">predicted</a> when discussing the company's results. “People will be happy to go out again, to socialize,” he said. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> The cosmetics industry was surprisingly resilient in 2020 as homebound people realized that Zoom’s touch-up-appearance feature could only do so much. </p>

<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Baby Yoda" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/krkrHAEodHgzP72rTI/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Hasbro’s <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MxDOsxSfIOI&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">animatronic Baby Yoda</a> won the Toy Association’s Toy of the Year award. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But the real winners? Toy companies. Hasbro and Mattel both reported <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/hasbro-mattel-say-toy-boom-to-extend-beyond-covid-19-11612963231?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">strong earnings</a> this week that reflected the broader industry’s 16% increase in sales in 2020. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“There is no question that the pandemic drove demand with kids staying at home. With the lockdowns, parents spent money on their children,” Mattel’s CEO, Ynon Kreiz, </span><span><a href="https://www.ft.com/content/2360f186-c8fe-495a-9cfd-cf0fd3424d39?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told the FT</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Another symbol of the Covid era: Mattel’s online sales grew more than 50% and now account for more than a third of its global retail sales.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Two categories boosted the industry</h2>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000"> Board games: </strong></span><span>Hasbro’s game sales jumped 15% last year, led by Operation, Monopoly, and...a Baby Yoda-themed version of Monopoly. Hasbro also acquired </span><span><em>Magic: The Gathering</em></span><span>, a card game with a cult following that’s grown during the pandemic, </span><span><a href="https://www.vice.com/en/article/g5pmw3/covid-19-magic-the-gathering-card-bans?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">especially online</a></span><span>. Uno cards sold well for Mattel. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000"> Dolls: </strong></span><span>Mattel’s doll sales grew 13% to $709 million, led by Barbies, American Girl, and </span><span><em>Star Wars </em></span><span>plushies (yes, featuring Baby Yoda).</span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2022 prediction: </strong>Disney spins off Baby Yoda as its own public company worth $150 billion.</p>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBrands Confront Olympic-Sized Controversy\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Two people standing behind human sized Olympic rings\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MDUyL29seW1waWNfcmluZ3MuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eCarl Court/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYou might think that running 100 meters in under 10 seconds or landing a Double McTwist 1260 would be the hardest things to do at the Olympics. But corporate sponsors are navigating an even bigger challenge: the delicate geopolitical and social issues surrounding the next two Olympics, in Tokyo and Beijing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eMore than 180 rights groups have \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/2022-beijing-winter-olympics-boycott-china-759c66df-df19-4f1b-92a1-744b98276dc9.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled for a boycott\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, citing the Chinese government’s many reported human rights violations. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAnd yesterday, the president of the Tokyo Olympic organizing committee, Yoshiro Mori, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/11/world/asia/yoshiro-mori-tokyo-olympics-resigns.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eresigned\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e after facing major blowback over his suggestion that women talk too much in meetings. Part of that blowback: Corporate sponsors started to rethink their involvement with the Games, according to Japanese media. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt’s left brands between a scandal and a hard place\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen China’s economy bounced back from the pandemic more quickly than Western countries, businesses became \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/olympic-sponsors-face-a-balancing-act-at-the-2022-beijing-games-11613145588?mod=hp_lead_pos11\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eeven more reliant\u003c/a\u003e on Chinese consumers. Nike, for instance, grew revenue 24% in China last quarter, compared to just 1% growth in North America.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat happens when you \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003cem\u003edo\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e speak out against China? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eLook at the NBA. It just returned to air in China nearly a year after former Houston Rockets GM Daryl Morey threw the league’s business relationship with Beijing into chaos after tweeting support for Hong Kong's pro-democracy protests. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, many advertisers are desperate for the eyeballs and brand association that come from having their logo next to a hand-springing Simone Biles. Live TV viewership was way down during Covid, and the Olympics were supposed to be a bounce-back moment for television advertising. But now the picture is murkier...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e...especially because the pandemic isn’t over. Japan won’t start vaccinating citizens until the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/02/03/sports/olympics/tokyo-olympics-playbook.html?action=click\u0026module=RelatedLinks\u0026pgtype=Article\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eend of February\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, and the Olympics are scheduled to start in July. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFor Beijing 2022, brands might get cover from the US government. The Biden administration has signaled that it \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-olympics-2022-beijing-usa/u-s-signals-no-plans-to-boycott-2022-beijing-winter-olympics-after-genocide-designation-idUSKBN2A332Z?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edoesn't support a boycott\u003c/a\u003e of the Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe UK economy just posted its \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/12/uk-economy-shrank-by-9point9percent-in-2020-its-largest-contraction-on-record.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elargest annual drop\u003c/a\u003e since Sir Isaac Newton was figuring out why things drop. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAccording to the Bank of England, 2020’s 9.9% contraction was the biggest blow to output since 1709, when the economy tanked 13% due to the “Great Frost”—the coldest European winter in the last 500+ years.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe 9.9% decline is more than double the GDP shrinkage that occured in 2009 following the financial crisis.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eIt’s also a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-britain-economy/uk-economy-slumps-by-record-10-in-2020-after-covid-hit-idUSKBN2AC0LA?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esteeper drop\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e than most other wealthy countries, including the US—whose economy fell 3.5% in 2020. Analysts say that could be because Britain’s economy relies more on face-to-face contact and recreation.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd despite tight restrictions on movement and business, the UK’s population still suffered greatly from the coronavirus, recording the highest death toll in Europe. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe UK could see a Ted Lasso-style turnaround in 2021. style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSales in the last three months of the year grew 4.8% on a style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe two main drivers of higher sales? Chinese online sales gained 56% (and total China revenue grew 27% in 2020).\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut like the Bucs when they signed Tom Brady, L’Oréal thinks the best is yet to come. href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-l-oreal-results/loreal-sees-post-pandemic-roaring-20s-driving-cosmetics-rebound-idUSKBN2AB26T?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epredicted\u003c/a\u003e when discussing the company's results. “People will be happy to go out again, to socialize,” he said. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e The cosmetics width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Hasbro’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MxDOsxSfIOI\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eanimatronic Baby Yoda\u003c/a\u003e won the Toy Association’s Toy of the Year award. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut the real winners? Toy companies. Hasbro and Mattel both reported \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/hasbro-mattel-say-toy-boom-to-extend-beyond-covid-19-11612963231?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estrong earnings\u003c/a\u003e this week that reflected the broader industry’s 16% increase in sales in 2020. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e“There is no question that the pandemic drove demand with kids staying at home. With the lockdowns, parents spent money on their children,” Mattel’s CEO, Ynon Kreiz, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/2360f186-c8fe-495a-9cfd-cf0fd3424d39?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold the FT\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnother symbol of the Covid era: Mattel’s online sales grew more than 50% and now account for more than a third of its global retail sales.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTwo categories boosted the industry\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e Board games: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHasbro’s game sales jumped 15% last year, led by Operation, Monopoly, and...a Baby Yoda-themed version of Monopoly. Hasbro also acquired \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eMagic: The Gathering\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, a card game with a cult following that’s grown during the pandemic, \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.vice.com/en/article/g5pmw3/covid-19-magic-the-gathering-card-bans?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eespecially online\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. Uno cards sold well for Mattel. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e Dolls: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMattel’s doll sales grew 13% to $709 million, led by Barbies, American Girl, and \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003eStar Wars \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eplushies (yes, featuring Baby Yoda).\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2022 prediction: \u003c/strong\u003eDisney spins off Baby Yoda as its own public company worth $150 billion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\"
